show.title: The Lost Boys
show.headline: A blood-sucking ’80s classic

event.title: <show-title>The Lost Boys</show-title>
event.headline: Joel Schumacher’s 1987 bisexual hot boy bloodsucking beach bonanza!
event.description:
“We don't ride with vampires.”

We’ve been waiting for this one! After writing THE WIZ (wild information, I know) and before deciding Batman’s suit needed nipples, Joel Schumacher directed one of the subtextually queerest mainstream films of the '80s. THE LOST BOYS is '80s homoeroticism distilled into its most potent form. When Michael (Jason Patric) and Sam Emerson (Corey Haim) move to the sleepy seaside town of Santa Carla, California, with their mother Lucy (Dianne Wiest), they're worried that life will suddenly become boring. Reeling from their parents' divorce and living with their mother’s eccentric father, Michael and Sam suddenly find their lives are anything but boring when they become the targets of a local hot boy vampire gang led by punky dangly earring-ed David (Kiefer Sutherland). Can Michael and Sam resist the thrall of homoerotic vampire ecstasy, or will they fall victim to the delicious seductions of the night?

Featuring an iconic '80s soundtrack, including a shirtless jacked saxophonist cover of "I Still Believe" and the banger “Cry Little Sister” by G Tom Mac, THE LOST BOYS is boy-on-boy queer-coded shenanigans at their finest. Some folks might argue with us that there is heterosexual romance in this film, but we disagree. I mean, every time they say the word “vampire,” it sounds like a gay slur, y’all. Sure, there’s always the incredible Star (Jami Gertz), but being drawn to a beautiful woman with giant hair isn’t straight – it’s actually super gay. Gays love big hair – it’s in our DNA. But for real though, THE LOST BOYS is Joel Schumacher at his most transparent; the dude wanted to make a movie about hot vampy boys and he did. And we’re not mad about it. Predating the brooding gaze of Edward Cullen, THE LOST BOYS was instrumental in bringing vampires one step further toward the sexy end of the sexy vs. scary spectrum, and we can’t wait to celebrate this camp classic with y’all on the big screen.

event.headline: Experience the final chapter of the ultimate zombie trilogy on the big screen
event.description: George A. Romero’s DAY OF THE DEAD, the apocalyptic final chapter of the ultimate zombie trilogy, returns to theaters for its 40th anniversary! Whole generations of horror lovers have never seen any of Romero’s zombie classics in theaters. Now in 2025, Red Band is thrilled for the opportunity to help fellow George A. Romero fans celebrate the 40th anniversary of the original DAY OF THE DEAD by seeing it as the legendary director intended – on the big screen!

event.title: <show-title>Wicked: For Good</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: A wickedly fun movie party awaits
event.description: Want to take your Oz experience over the rainbow? Join us for a WICKED: FOR GOOD Movie Party, where the magic doesn’t stop at the screen. Come dressed to impress for our costume contest – there’s a fun giveaway for the most spellbinding look – and every guest will receive a bag of enchanting goodies: a Grimmerie field notebook for jotting down spells, a Green Elixir bubble bath mixer for some wicked self-care, a loofah inspired by Glinda’s iconic gown, a wind-up butterfly to release during the wedding scene, a storm cloud ribbon wand to whip up your own mini tornados, and a witch hat hair clip to top it all off. It’s the ultimate interactive celebration for good witches, bad witches, and everyone in between.

contentBlocks.paragraphs: Want to take your Oz experience over the rainbow? Join us for a WICKED: FOR GOOD Movie Party, where the magic doesn’t stop at the screen.

show.title: Back to the Future: 40th Anniversary
show.headline: Marty McFly's time traveling causes a chain reaction that could end his future

event.title: <show-title>Back to the Future: 40th Anniversary</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Come get heavy with Marty and Doc
event.description:
"1.21 gigawatts!”

40 years ago, Michael J. Fox and Christopher Lloyd took us on an era-hopping adventure with BACK TO THE FUTURE as the '80s raddest time-travelin' teen and his unlikely sidekick – a crazy, wild-eyed, wild-haired scientist. What rose from those flame trails is the heaviest sci-fi comedy ever made – one that is often considered "the perfect movie" without hyperbole.

Now, you’re invited to get even heavier with us at these fourth wall-busting celebrations of time-hopping DeLoreans, life jacket vests, and oedipal overtones. Come floor it with us right to 88 mph with a Johnny B. Goode air guitar contest before the show, and themed props to bring the movie magic to life, like your very own vial of Plutonium!*

*Not guaranteed to actually transport you back in time.

It’s the raucously fun celebration you might not be ready for, but your kids – your kids are gonna love it.

show.title: Branded to Kill
show.headline: Seijun Suzuki's fractured pop art yakuza noir

event.title: <show-title>Branded to Kill</show-title>
event.headline: Seijun Suzuki’s 1967 psychosexual oddball yakuza masterpiece!
event.description:
“A killer mustn't be human. He must be tough and cool.”

In the 1960s, Japanese cinema was in the midst of a renaissance, referred to as the Japanese New Wave period. Supported financially by the studio system, directors like Yoshishige Yoshida, Masahiro Shinoda, and Seijun Suzuki were able to create widely seen films that explored the further reaches of radical politics, violence, sexuality, queerness, and marginalization. Suzuki, in particular, was incredibly prolific, directing 40 films for the Nikkatsu Company from 1956 to 1967 before the film that almost ruined him, his magnum opus, BRANDED TO KILL.

(Deep breath) This movie is bizarre, y’all. Psychosexual, bitingly satirical, and dreamily nonsensical. This picture’s a trip. BRANDED TO KILL follows the absurd and surreal journey of hitman Goro Hanada (Joe Shishido) as he flounders a mission from femme fatale Misako Nakajo (Annu Mari) and becomes the target of No. 1 Killer (Koji Nonbara), the best hitman in the business. Reveling in fractured masculinity, esoteric fetishes, and delirious forms of desire, BRANDED TO KILL is an absurdist masterpiece that queers the yakuza crime genre. Financially unsuccessful and critically panned, BRANDED TO KILL led to Suzuki being fired by the Nikkatsu Company for “making movies that make no sense and no money.” As is often the case, the misunderstood work of art went on to gather a cult following and is now appreciated for the unique, sleezy gem that it is. And we can’t wait to showcase it as part of your favorite misunderstood cult screening series, Queer Film Theory 101.

show.title: Blood Rage
show.headline: It’s not cranberry sauce

event.title: <show-title>Blood Rage</show-title>
event.headline: It’s not cranberry sauce
event.description:
Thanksgiving isn’t Thanksgiving without a viewing of BLOOD RAGE. Produced by whip-smart filmmaker Maryanne Kantor and shot in Florida, this essential party slasher is what happens when you combine Thanksgiving, 1970s TV star Louise Lasser, a killer synth score, and the most unbelievable gore effects in all of slasherdom, courtesy Ed French (TERMINATOR 2). Remember: “It’s not cranberry sauce.”

Restoration courtesy of Arrow Films and the American Genre Film Archive

show.title: Ringu
show.headline: The J-Horror classic returns to theaters with a new restoration

event.title: <show-title>Ringu</show-title> <event-type-title>4K Restoration</event-type-title>
event.headline: The J-Horror classic returns to theaters in a new restoration
event.description:
Television journalist Reiko investigates an urban legend about a cursed VHS tape that murders the viewer seven days after they watch it. As the mystery hits closer to home, Reiko joins forces with ex-husband/current-exorcist Takashi to destroy the curse. And (hopefully) survive an encounter with a ghost named Sadako. Directed by Hideo Nakata (DARK WATER), RINGU is the highest grossing Japanese horror movie in history that STILL manages to shred our nerves with its quiet, phantasmic elegance. This is the only VHS fetish movie in history to inspire an entire subgenre, as well as dozens of remakes and rip-offs. Criminally absent from theaters since its original theatrical release in 1998, the time is now for RINGU to terrify the world. Again.

Restoration courtesy of Arrow Films and the American Genre Film Archive.

show.title: The Beyond (1981)
show.headline: Lucio Fulci's gateway to gore-soaked annihilation

event.title: <show-title>The Beyond (1981)</show-title> <event-type-title>Composer's Cut</event-type-title>
event.headline: Lucio Fulci's gateway to gore-soaked annihilation
event.description:
Fulci’s THE BEYOND is an Italian horror that is a galaxy-shaking tour de force. When an abandoned Louisiana hotel is re-opened, new owner Liza (Katherine MacColl, THE HOUSE BY THE CEMETERY) discovers that things aren't right. That’s because the hotel is a gateway to human extinction due to eyeless zombies, possessed tarantulas, and toxic Slurpees.

The apex of Fulci's "Gates Of Hell" trilogy, THE BEYOND feels like what would happen inside Salvador Dali’s brain if he took acid and watched THE SHINING. As you'd expect with any gore-fest that bears the Fulci name, this movie is rife with gorgeous photography, epic mythology, and killer synth-prog earthquakes courtesy Fabio Frizzi.

event.title: <show-title>The Descent</show-title> <event-type-title>20th Anniversary</event-type-title>
event.headline: A rare screening of the unrated UK Cut, presented in a new 4K Restoration
event.description: We don't just watch horror movies — we live for them. And at every Terror Tuesday, we join hands to worship at the gore-soaked altar of slash, trash, thrash, and FUN!! This eclectic series spans all centuries, covering everything from seminal horror treasures to undiscovered D.I.Y. monster-blasts. Terror Tuesday is the new ground zero for warming your black heart.

show.title: Cruel Jaws
show.headline: The high-water mark of Italian JAWSploitation

event.title: <show-title>Cruel Jaws</show-title>
event.headline: The high-water mark of Italian JAWSploitation.
event.description:
“As far as copping Spielberg's classic goes, nothing compares to CRUEL JAWS...the granddaddy of all rip-offs.” -- Jeremy Wheeler, ALLMOVIE

He defied all laws of good taste and international copyright with TERMINATOR 2: SHOCKING DARK and ROBOWAR. He reset the bar for batshit Italo horror with RATS: NIGHT OF TERROR. And in 1995, Bruno Mattei stunned the world with CRUEL JAWS: the ultimate sharksploitation saga. Filmed in Florida with a cast of unknowns (including a Hulk Hogan lookalike), this film liberally borrows characters, plot, and footage from a number of other Italian sharksploitationers...and more famous sources. Experience the epitome of outrageous Italian rip-offs, now remastered and uncut for the very first time!

DCP courtesy of Vinegar Syndrome and the American Genre Film Archive

show.title: The Erotic Rites of Frankenstein
show.headline: An ultra-stylish gothic blast from Jess Franco.

event.title: <show-title>The Erotic Rites of Frankenstein</show-title>
event.headline: An ultra-stylish gothic blast from Jess Franco.
event.description: Dr. Frankenstein is murdered just as he manages to finally bring his creature to life. The assailants—the evil sorcerer Caligostro and his half-bird henchman Melissa—plan to use the creature to create a new race of super-beings and take over the world. The problem: they need to find a mate. As they set about doing that, Frankenstein’s daughter tries to wrest back control of the creature before it’s too late. One of Spanish genre cinema legend Jess Franco’s most purely enjoyable movies, THE EROTIC RITES OF FRANKENSTEIN is an outrageously kinky monster mash that plays like a live action fumetti.

show.title: Who Killed Teddy Bear?
show.headline: Prime cut mid century exploitation, newly restored.

event.title: <show-title>Who Killed Teddy Bear?</show-title>
event.headline: Prime cut mid century exploitation, newly restored.
event.description:
One of the darkest stories to ever come of out of the Big Apple, WHO KILLED TEDDY BEAR? is a dark and twisted dive into toxic masculinity featuring a shocking central performance from Sal Mineo (REBEL WITHOUT A CAUSE). When a club singer receives a string of obscene calls from a mysterious stalker, her pleas for help get her caught between the desires of two damaged men: the tragic detective looking to catch her harasser, and the shy coworker (Sal Mineo) whose boyish looks disguise a dangerous dark side. Infamously rejected by the British Board of Film Classification and misunderstood by both audiences and critics of the era, WHO KILLED TEDDY BEAR? has since gone on to inspire countless genre classics since and proven its rightful place as a harrowing New York City masterpiece.

DCP courtesy of Vinegar Syndrome and the American Genre Film Archive

show.title: Creepshow (1982)
show.headline: Stephen King and George Romero's horror anthology

event.title: <show-title>Creepshow (1982)</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Stephen King and George Romero's horror anthology
event.description:
Fans of Stephen King know that even though he’s written some seriously epic novels, some of his best work lies within his short stories. Whether he wants to scare you, move you, or make you laugh, he knows how to get there quickly and masterfully.

And that’s what makes CREEPSHOW so great. Alongside legendary director George Romero (NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD), King crafted a series of tales into a film that stands as the seminal ’80s horror anthology.

Featuring an amazing cast, including Adrienne Barbeau (THE FOG), Leslie Nielsen (THE NAKED GUN), and Ted Danson (BODY HEAT), CREEPSHOW is a pop-art splatterfest that’s oozing with senior citizen zombies, bad dads, furry beasties, disco dance-offs, cockroach war zones, and Stephen King turning into a plant. You can’t go wrong.

Your ticket comes with the following props:

  • Brain gummies
  • A pumpkin scoop
  • A jack-o-lantern light

And that’s what makes CREEPSHOW so great. Alongside legendary director George Romero (NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD), King crafted a series of tales into a film that stands as the seminal ’80s horror anthology.

Featuring an amazing cast, including Adrienne Barbeau (THE FOG), Leslie Nielsen (THE NAKED GUN), and Ted Danson (BODY HEAT), CREEPSHOW is a pop-art splatterfest that’s oozing with senior citizen zombies, bad dads, furry beasties, disco dance-offs, cockroach war zones, and Stephen King turning into a plant. eventType.title: Movie Party
eventType.headline: Celebrate your fave movies with fun, interactive props, themed drinks, and more
eventType.description: Spanning all genres, Alamo Drafthouse Movie Parties are an immersive, interactive experience for cinema fans featuring fun props, themed drinks, and more.

show.title: The Craft
show.headline: Light as a feather, stiff as a board

show.title: The Mummy (1999)
show.headline: The sands will rise. The heavens will part. The power will be unleashed.

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: All Ages
sessionAttributes.description: For all ages shows, we welcome babies and kids of all ages. The no talking rules are relaxed, since kids will be kids. But other than that, you can expect the full Alamo experience.

sessionAttributes.name: Kid Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Grab the fam and let the fun begin! Our Kid Friendly screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. Ages 3+ welcome with a parent or guardian.

formats.description: Digital format projected using a digital projector.

formats.title: 35mm
formats.headline: Film print projected using film projectors.
formats.description: The industry standard for theatrical film releases prior to digital cinema. Film print projected using film projectors.

agePolicies.name: All Ages
agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.
